entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management – Part 4 (New Feature)
entry.content:
Multi-Company Integration: Scaling Across LoBs and Source Systems

In this blog part, I’ll dive into a major breakthrough released in December 2025: the ability to support N:N integration scenarios in Multiple Company integration scenario between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Field Management.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Part 4 - Multi-Company Integration: Scaling Across LoBs and Source Systems

Previously, integrating master data from multiple source systems or Line of Businesses (LoBs) or Regions into multiple SAP FSM companies was a technical bottleneck. The standard integration content relied on a single Multiple Company Value Mapping artifact to manage company determination. This meant you couldn't easily maintain distinct mapping rules for different regions, or LoBs, or S/4HANA systems within a single SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) tenant.

This limitation is now a thing of the past.

Enabling N:N Integration via Value Mapping Prefixes

The latest update introduces a flexible strategy to support multiple S/4HANA sources or LoBs, each requiring its own unique multi-company mapping criteria. By using a Value Mapping Prefix, you can now deploy distinct mapping rules side-by-side in the same environment.

How it Works

  • Unique Identifiers: You can now assign a unique prefix (e.g., LOB1_ or REGION_A_) to your multiple company Value Mapping artifacts.
  • Independent Artifacts: Instead of one giant mapping table, the system creates separate, dedicated artifacts (e.g., LOB1_AccountCompany) for each specific source or business unit.
  • End-to-End Consistency: By configuring this prefix across all relevant integration flows, you ensure that data from Source A always follows Rule A, and Source B always follows Rule B.

Configuration Steps: How to Set It Up

To enable this, a new external parameter, ValueMappingPrefix, has been added to the standard suite of interfaces.

  1. Update Your Interfaces

You must configure the prefix value in the following standard iFlows to ensure they recognize the specific mapping rules for that LoB:

  • Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping Configuration
  • Replicate Business Partner (and Contacts/Relationships)
  • Replicate Products, Product Stock, and Product Price
  • Replicate Item Groups
  • Replicate Service Orders (SOAP)
  1. Practical Example

If you are setting up integration for "Line of Business 1":

  • Configure the Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping iFlow with the prefix LOB1_.
  • Deploy the iFlow. This automatically generates a new artifact named: LOB1_Value Mapping for Multiple Company determination in SAP FSM from SAP S4HANA.
  • Now, all data tagged with LOB1_ will use these specific rules, keeping your global configuration clean and organized.

  • Once your multi-company configuration has been synchronized to SAP Cloud Integration, you are ready to configure and deploy the master data iFlows. Ensure you specify the correct ValueMappingPrefix in each interface to route data accurately from S/4HANA to FSM, as shown in the example below:

Best Practices for Implementation

Pro Tip: To keep your integration landscape manageable, copy the standard package (“SAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Field Service Management”) for each distinct LoB.

For each copied package:

  • Assign the unique prefix consistently across all iFlows within that package.
  • Synchronize sequentially: Update your mapping configuration in S/4HANA for one LoB at a time, then deploy the corresponding synchronization iFlow to push those rules to CPI.

Summary of Benefits

  • Scalability: Manage multiple S/4HANA systems in a single CPI tenant without data collisions.
  • Flexibility: Define region-specific or business-unit-specific rules for how data maps to FSM companies.
  • Reduced Complexity: No need for multiple CPI tenants to handle different business segments.

 

Note: This is an advanced configuration intended specifically for N:N integration scenarios (multiple source systems to multiple FSM companies) within a single SAP Cloud Integration tenant. By default, the ValueMappingPrefix is blank, supporting the standard 1:N integration (single S/4HANA source to multiple FSM companies).

entry.title: Canada T4A-NR 2025 Regulatory Changes: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance(DRC)
entry.content:
Towards the end of 2025, the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) rolled out updates to the T4A-NR slip, summary forms, and the T619 XML schema. These changes, which will affect filings due on or before the last day of February 2026, have been seamlessly integrated into SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solutions, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition /On-Premise. Here’s a detailed look at what these updates entail and how SAP is ensuring compliance.

Key Regulatory Changes

  1. Updated CRA Forms: The CRA has released new 2025 versions of the T4A-NR slip and the T4A-NR Summary (T4A-NR-SUM) for the 2025 tax year. While the content changes are minimal, using the correct form version is essential to avoid filing issues.
  2. T619 XML Schema Updates:
    • Mandatory Language Code: To ensure consistent language identification for CRA communications, the T619 electronic transmittal now requires a language code to specify English or French, denoted by “E” or “F” for every submission. Previously optional, this field is now mandatory for 2025 filings.
    • No Empty Fields in XML: A new validation rule mandates that any optional XML element with no data must be omitted entirely. This means if a data field doesn’t apply or is blank, the system should not generate that XML tag at all, as including empty tags can lead to file rejection by the CRA. 

SAP's Support of Regulatory Changes

As part ofSAP’s end-to-end compliance vision, the SAP Globalization Product Management team has proactively delivered the necessary updates to accommodate these CRA changes, to ensure that customers can generate compliant T4A-NR slips, summaries, and XML files across SAP Cloud ERP solutions:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: The T4A-NR form and summary Adobe print forms have been updated in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to match the CRA’s 2025 PDF layout. Electronic filing content for T4A-NR has been enhanced to output XML according to the new schema, delivered via the regular quarterly release.
  •  SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition/On-Premise: SAP Note 3691523 – “Canada T4A-NR Withholding Tax Reporting: Legal Changes 2025” was released, along with a support package containing the updated forms and electronic report definitions. Applying this note or support pack will ensure the system produces the correct 2025 forms and XML.

Next Steps 

  • Review and Implement SAP Update: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system has the 2025 year-end legal change for T4A-NR applied. For SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, apply SAP Note 3691523. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, confirm you’re on the latest release that includes the T4A-NR changes. Implement these updates before year-end processing.
  • Test Your Reporting: Generate a sample T4A-NR slip, summary, and XML file in a test environment. Verify that the slip and summary display “2025” and the latest form text. Ensure the language element is present and correctly set, and confirm that there are no empty tags in the file.
  • Consult CRA Resources: Refer to the CRA’s official XML specifications page for the updated schema download and guidance for 2025/2026 filings. The CRA’s T4A-NR guide (RC4445) for 2025, updated December 2025, is also a helpful reference. Links to the schema files and CRA documentation are available on the CRA website.

Call to Action

SAP customers and partners can avoid last-minute scrambles and ensure a smooth tax filing season by taking the following actions:

  • Review our published "What's New" SAP Help Portal documentation, apply, and test the delivered SAP changes promptly.
  • Engage your IT or SAP support team to confirm that your system is outputting the new form and schema correctly. Leverage the Regulatory Change Manager for agility in adapting to new legal requirements.
  • Visit the CRA’s XML specification page for the official schema and test your files against it. With proper preparation, you’ll be ready to file your 2025 T4A‑NR returns without issues.
  • Connect with us via the SAP support channels or Canada Localization Workzone if questions arise during this update process.

entry.title: SAP Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (PCE) - Detailed steps
entry.content:
SAP Joule is SAP’s next-generation generative AI assistant designed to transform how users interact with SAP systems. Integrated across the SAP ecosystem, Joule enables natural language conversations that help users navigate applications, retrieve business insights, and perform transactions without traditional menus or manual steps. By understanding real business context, Joule guides users to the right Fiori apps, executes tasks such as displaying purchase orders or creating sales documents, and provides intelligent insights drawn from S/4HANA and other SAP solutions. This elevates user productivity, reduces training effort, and delivers a more intuitive, conversational SAP experience.  

This guide walks through the setup of Joule for an SAP S/4HANA Cloud PCE system. It is based on hands-on implementation experience and is written to help consultants and administrators perform the setup efficiently. 

Capabilities of Joule 

SAP Joule offers three major capability categories that help users interact with SAP systems through natural language: 

  • Transactional Capabilities 

Joule can perform business transactions on behalf of the user by invoking S/4HANA APIs and Fiori applications. 

  • Navigational Capabilities 

Joule can navigate users to the correct SAP Fiori apps based on their request. 

  • Informational Capabilities 

Joule provides conversational insights and general information from SAP documentation and system context. 

Architecture Diagram 

 

SAP Joule is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition starting from version 2021 and above. 

How to Get Access to SAP Joule 

  • New RISE contracts → auto entitled. 
  • Existing RISE customers → request entitlement from Account Executive. 

Prerequisites 

  • SAP BTP with Joule, work zone, cloud identity service, cloud foundry services 
  • SAP Cloud Connector 
  • SAP Cloud identity services 
  • SAP S/4HANA private cloud system 

 

Let’s get started with the configuration. 

We will divide the configuration steps into four main parts.. 

1. SAP BTP configuration 

1.1 Validate S/4HANA private cloud system is included in the landscape. 

1.2 Make sure the entitlements for Joule, Work zone, and Cloud identity services are available 

1.3 Create a subaccount for Joule and include the above-mentioned services in the subaccount. 

Tip: Subaccount should be created in a region where the Cloud identity service is located if we are using only one subaccount for all services. If we are using a separate subaccount for cloud identity services, then we must choose a region which is same or near to S/4HANA system for the Joule subaccount. 

 1.4 Establish trust with cloud identity services 

 1.5 Run Joule Booster 

 

Select S/4HANA cloud private edition as the capability and include work zone and cloud identity services in the integration setup and complete the booster run 

 

 

 

1.6 Activate work zone and cloud identity services 

1.7 Create work zone key and enable cloud foundry 

 

 

 

 

 1.8 Create destinations 

Create the below destinations in BTP 

1.8.1 Create a design time destination with basic authentication. This is the destination which sends the content from S/4HANA system to work zone. Also, give the client property in the destination. 

1.8.2 Create runtime destination with proxy type internet and no authentication. This is the destination which is used to retrieve the data from S/4 system in runtime. 

1.8.3 Create private cloud destinations with principal propagation. This is the destination used to retrieve nominations through the SAP cloud connector. 

1.8.4 Create single sign on destination with principal propagation 

1.8.5 Create Navigation destination with details of work zone 

1.8.6Create RFC destination with basic authentication for identity provisioning 

 

 1.9 Create content Provider 

A content provider is simply a system or source that supplies data or content to another application. The receiving system uses this provided content to show data, answer questions, or perform actions. 

 

 1.10 Add S/4HANA private cloud domain to trusted domain names in both BTP and IAS 

 2. Cloud connector 

In the cloud connector we need to create a subaccount for Joule by providing the BTP subaccount details such as region, subaccount id, Display name email and password. 

 

 

Create one HTTPS connection and an RFC connection to the backend S/4HANA system and make sure the HTTPS connection is set with principal propagation and connection is working to the backend. 

Tip: Principal propagation configuration is a mandatory step for Joule to work with S/4HANA private cloud and make sure this configuration is completed and working.  

 3. Cloud identity services 

Configure cloud identity services to create source and destination systems. 

We need to add source and target systems to the cloud identity services to process the user roles and groups in the SAP work zone. 

Source system and target systems creating Json script are available on the below page 

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/configure-identity-provisioning-service-a6cf317ecede4fa78c57be07219cee1a 

Once the systems are created, the next step is to run the read/sync job which will create the users and corresponding roles and groups in the work zone to support Joule functionality.  

 

 4. S/4HANA system 

4.1 Create a technical user with the roles SAP_BC_JSF_COMMUNICATION_RO Profiles and profile SAP_ALL. This user is used for communication of joule with S/4 HANA system wherever basic authentication is used. 

4.2 Create Technical and Business Catalog in S/4HANA system. First, create the technical catalog with the details below and add this technical catalog to the business catalog. 

 

Field 

Value 

Application Type 

SAP UI5 Fiori App 

Semantic Object 

Shell 

Action 

plugin 

SAPUI5 Component ID 

sap.das.webclientplugin.s4 

ICF Path 

URL with Joule application’s hostname, and with /resources/public/webclient/s4 appended 

Suppress Tile 

Checked 

Application Component ID 

CA-FLP-ABA 

Target Application Title 

Joule 

Information 

Optional: Enter a description of your plug-in. 

Device Types 

Select the device or devices that are supported by your plug-in, e.g. desktop or phone. The plug-in will only be shown on these selected devices. 

Parameters 

Define parameters that you want to pass to the plug-in component by entering a name and a default value for each parameter. 

 4.3 Create a role in the system and add this business catalog to the role. 

This role is required for all the users who are using joule to see the joule icon in the Fiori Launchpad. Assign this role to the Joule users. 

 4.4 Activate OData services. Identify the list of OData services which are required to be activated in the system based on the joule capabilities and make sure the respective ICF services are also activated. 

4.5 Expose roles from CDM3. List all the roles based on the joule capabilities that are being used and expose all those roles to BTP. 

Once the roles are exposed, we can see these roles in the content manager of BTP work zone after updating the channel manager. 

Assign the roles to the users. Make sure the roles based on Joule capabilities are assigned to the users who are using Joule. 

This summarizes the complete end-to-end configuration required to activate SAP Joule for S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. 

Joule Icon will be available as below in the Fiori launchpad and we can login with the IAS credentials.

entry.title: Legal Change - IDIS scenario support through Extensibility in DRC Türkiye
entry.content:
This blog post provides a step-by-step guide on how to implement the new legal requirement released by GIB (GELİR İDARESİ BAŞKANLIĞI) for eInvoice and eDespatch under the Construction Rebar Tracking System (IDIS) using Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Background:
We have already published a blog titled Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud which explains how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud customers can leverage developer extensibility to modify the content of XML files generated during electronic invoice submissions, in accordance with specific business and legal requirements.

Note for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments:
In SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP ECC environments, the same extensibility approach is available. However, in these systems, the BAdI implementation must be carried out for EDOC_ADAPTOR instead of EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD.

What’s New?
GIB has published a legal requirement for invoices issued under the Construction Rebar Tracking System, which impacts certain companies starting from 21st November 2025. In this blog, we aim to address this requirement by building on the learnings from the previous blog highlighted in the background.

What are the technical specifications of the requirement?
Currently, the system does not automatically determine whether a billing or finance document is related to the Construction Rebar Tracking  System. Customers must explicitly indicate that the invoice belongs to a Construction Rebar Tracking System and provide the required values.
As part of the legal requirements published by the authorities, the following new Profile IDs must be used in the UBL (Universal Business Language, an ISO standard XML) representation:

  1. IDIS - for eInvoice Scenarios
  2. IDISIRSALIYE – for eDespatch scenarios

eInvoice

  • ProfileID for IDIS Scenario
    For IDIS-relevant invoices, the ProfileID in the UBL-TR XML will be set to IDIS.
    • Cardinality: 1 (Mandatory)
    • This value determines that the invoice belongs to the IDIS scenario
    • The solution will automatically populate this value for applicable

  • Shipment Number (Sevkiyat Numarası) at Header Level:
    • Mapped to: Invoice/AccountingSupplierParty/Party/PartyIdentification
      SE-<number> with schemeID as SEVKIYATINO – This would carry the shipment number prefixed with SE. The total number of characters is 10.
      Example: SE-1345840
    • IssueDate should be filled with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format

  • Tag Number (Etiket Numarası) at Item Level:
    • Invoice/InvoiceLine/Item/AdditionalItemIdentification/ID should be filled with tag number generated within the scope of IDIS (Rebar Monitoring System). This number is a 9-character alphanumeric value, where the first 2 characters are letters followed by 7 numeric digits. 
      SchemeID should be ETIKETNO.
      Example: CV0152457

eDespatch

  • ProfileID for IDISIRSALIYE Scenario
    For IDISIRSALIYE-relevant invoices, the ProfileID in the UBL-TR XML will be set to IDISIRSALIYE.
    • Cardinality: 1 (Mandatory)
    • This value determines that the invoice belongs to the IDISIRSALIYE scenario
    • The solution will automatically populate this value for applicable

  • Shipment Number (Sevkiyat Numarası) at Header Level:
    • Mapped to: /DespatchAdvice/DespatchSupplierParty/Party/PartyIdentification
      SE-<number> with schemeID as SEVKIYATINO – This would carry the shipment number prefixed with SE. The total number of characters is 10.
      Example: SE-1345840
    • IssueDate should be filled with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format

  • Tag Number (Etiket Numarası) at Item Level:
    • /DespatchAdvice/DespatchLine/Item/AdditionalItemIdentification/ID should be filled with tag number generated within the scope of IDIS (Rebar Monitoring System). This number is a 9-character alphanumeric value, where the first 2 characters are letters followed by 7 numeric digits. 
      SchemeID should be ETIKETNO.
      Example: CV0152457

Result:
When you display the XML file of the electronic document in the eDocument Cockpit (EDOC_COCKPIT) corresponding to the above invoicing scenario, you will see that the mentioned tags are populated accordingly. Please note that any error handling and troubleshooting will depend on the actual submission of this document to the authorized service provider.

Conclusion:
With recent enhancements to the Türkiye Document and Reporting Compliance solution, SAP has made it significantly easier to tailor electronic document outputs.
This improvement gives you more flexibility and helps ensure compliance with Türkiye’s legal requirements.

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table  

Have you ever been in a situation where you wanted to add a key user custom field to a given database table (e.g. ACDOCA or VBAK), but you did not know which business context to choose? 

Or are you right in the middle of an ECC to SAP S/4HANA migration project, and you have legacy custom fields in your ECC system? You want to recreate custom fields in SAP S/4HANA, and you don’t know which business context to choose?  

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you’ll find out how to determine the right business context based on a given database table name (or CI-include name or extension include name). 
The ways to determine the right business context differ between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (and on premise).

How do business contexts relate to database tables?  

When you create a custom field using the Custom Fields app, you must first choose a business context. A business context describes the business entity which you want to extend. Technically, each business context has an include structure assigned, which is directly or transitively included in one or more database tables. This include structure is also called persistence include or extension include structure. 
If you add a custom field to a business context, this field is added to the respective persistence include structure using an append structure. With that, all database tables and structures which include this persistence include structure automatically also get this field. 

You can get more detailed information in the following SAP Help documentation: Handling_of_Legacy_Fields.pdf 
 
Now that you have an idea of how business contexts relate to database tables, let’s understand  

  1. how to figure out the respective business context for a given database table and 
  1. how to figure out the database table(s) which get extended when you add a field to a business context 

Figuring out the business context based on a given object in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_BUS_CTXTS_BY_DB_TABLE allows you to enter a database table name, a CI-include name, or an extension include name. When running the report, all business contexts that expose fields in the respective database table/CI-include/extension include are listed. 
This report is part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table

Figuring out database table(s) that are extended by a business context in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_DB_TABLES_BY_BUS_CTXT allows you to enter a business context name. As a result, a list of all database tables that contain the fields of the given business context is displayed. This report is also part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table 

Figuring out the business context based on a given database table in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can use the Extensibility Assistant (see this blog for details) that helps you to create and maintain custom fields. In one of the next releases (probably already with the 2608 release) the Extensibility Assistant will also be able to tell you which business context to choose to extend a given database table. If you enter a prompt like “Which business context should I use in order to extend table VBAK?”, the extensibility assistant will be able to help you. 

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij),  and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions.

entry.title: Why Vectorized Master Data is Critical for AI on SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Why Most AI Agents Fail with SAP Data

AI Agents are rapidly becoming part of enterprise landscapes, and SAP ECC and S/4HANA are obvious targets for automation. However, what we see in the market today is concerning.

Most agentic solutions attempt to consume SAP data through custom coding. This approach creates three major problems:

  1. High development and maintenance costs

  2. Multiple, inefficient calls to the SAP backend

  3. Mass data extraction, where AI Agents pull entire tables just to find a few relevant records

In many of the solutions we reviewed, including agentic SDKs integrations such as Joule, n8n, ChatGPT, and Claude, AI Agents frequently fail, time out, or request all records from SAP ERP systems with minimal filtering. This is inefficient, risky, and completely unnecessary.

At Skybuffer AI, we believe there is a better way.

The Foundation: Preparing SAP Data for AI Consumption

Data preparation is the key to successful AI-driven automation. While topics like data silos and data quality are well known, they cannot be fully solved overnight. Instead of fighting this reality, Skybuffer AI introduces a simple and reliable data layer that AI Agents can consume efficiently.

Skybuffer AI uses SAP master data vectorization to enable fast, accurate access to SAP ECC and S/4HANA data from agentic workflows. Any SAP master data table, including views and CDS views, can be vectorized and materialized using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Key capabilities include:

  • Support for full and delta loads

  • Near real-time synchronization with SAP

  • A scalable, AI-ready representation of SAP master data

 Pic. 1 Skybuffer AI – SAP Data Vectorization Configuration

Performance at Enterprise Scale

A common concern is performance. Vectorizing SAP master data row by row would indeed be slow, if done sequentially.

Skybuffer AI solves this with parallel embedding execution, allowing vectorization at enterprise scale. On servers with 8 GPUs, Skybuffer AI can process up to 1 million records in 30 minutes. That is scalable in case even faster vectorization solution is needed.

More importantly, once initial vectorization is complete, a self-healing delta mechanism ensures that only new or changed records are processed. This keeps the data current without impacting performance.

Business Value: Why This Approach Matters

The benefits are immediate and measurable:

  • No coding for intelligent master data search

  • No multiple calls to SAP backend systems

  • No full-table reads triggered by AI Agents

  • Faster, more reliable AI-driven processes

Consider a real-world scenario:
A vendor invoice arrives by email.

Pic. 2 Real Consumption-Based Invoice Example

The AI Agent reads the email and attachment, extracts the vendor name exactly as written on the invoice, and needs the corresponding SAP vendor number. Instead of querying SAP repeatedly or scanning entire tables, the Agent performs one single RAG search against vectorized SAP master data.

Within milliseconds, the correct vendor record is returned. It is accurate, up to date, and ready for posting in SAP.

Pic. 3 Skybuffer AI – Fast and Reliable SAP Data Search Using Data Vectorization

No coding. No overload. No hallucinations.

Applicable Across Many SAP Use Cases

The same approach works seamlessly across multiple scenarios, including:

  • Finding SAP users or business objects by name, email address, or other attributes

  • Creating Sales Orders in SAP from customer Purchase Orders

  • Resolving customer and material master data automatically

  • Creating Bills of Materials and routings from Excel files managed by R&D teams

  • Posting Service Entry Sheets

  • Rapidly enabling new use cases by simply nominating tables for vectorization

If the data exists in SAP, it can be prepared for AI consumption.

Built-In Authorization and Security

Security is not an afterthought.

Skybuffer AI applies the same concept used in AI assistants for Teams, Copilot, and Joule, so vectorized data accessed by users with an additional safeguard. Once the AI Agent selects relevant records via RAG, Skybuffer AI retrieves those records directly from SAP using SSO within the active conversation session, before providing data to the user.

This ensures:

  • Users only see data they are authorized to access in SAP

  • Vectorized data never bypasses SAP authorization rules

  • Enterprise-grade compliance and governance

Seamless Integration with Existing AI Agents

Already running AI Agents and just need access to SAP data?

Skybuffer AI provides an MCP Server, allowing your existing agentic solutions to consume vectorized SAP data without replacing your current platform. This makes Skybuffer AI an enabler, not a disruptor.

 Pic. 4 Skybuffer AI – MCP Server for Integration with Agentic SDK

Flexible Deployment: Cloud or On-Premise

Skybuffer AI is built on SAP HANA and can be deployed:

  • On-premise within your own infrastructure

  • In your SAP BTP tenant

A modern SAP UI5 user interface ensures an intuitive and productive user experience for both IT and business users.

Conclusion

SAP ECC and S/4HANA master data vectorization is the missing link between SAP and AI Agents.

With Skybuffer AI, enterprises can:

  • Eliminate coding

  • Avoid hallucinations

  • Reduce SAP backend load

  • Enable fast, secure, and reliable AI-driven processes

This is how SAP data becomes truly AI-ready.

entry.title: Tools in Service Transactions
entry.content:
You are a service manager

  • You create a service order to plan a service on customer site. 
  • You identify that this certain service can only be carried out using a specific tool such as a lifting platform.
  • You are wondering how you can use such tools in your service order.

Solution

  • In this blog I am going to explain how you can enable products as tools that can be used in service transactions.

 

Configurations in Customizing

Configurations are to be done that are are prerequisites for creation of products as tools.

Change Material Type FHMI

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Material Types -> Define Attributes of Material Types. 
  • You flag the checkbox for material type FHMI with description Production Resource/Tool and open the details.
  • You flag the checkbox Sales in the box User departments. (See screenshot in Figure 1.)  

Figure 1: Change view “Material types” for material type FHMI (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Change Screen Sequences

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Configuring the Material Master -> Define Structure of Data Screens for Each Screen Sequence.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 with description Std ind.(short) tab pages and double-click on Data screens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 and screen 17, then you double-click on Subscreens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you change the program of screen sequence 21, screen 17, and subscreen 4 from SAPLMGD1 to SAPLCRMS4_PRUDUCT_SUBSCREEN. (See screenshot in Figure 2.)  

Figure 2: View Subscreens (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Maintain status for MARA-SRV_DURA and MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • In displayed view search for field name MARA-SRV_DURA and double-click on this line so the view Field Groups is opened. In this view change the maintenance status from V to VF. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 
  • You do the same for field name MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM.

Figure 3: View Field Groups for field name MARA-SRV_DURA (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Hide MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI for material type FHMI

Since the fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tools used in service transactions, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI.

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • You choose a new field selection group for the two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL (Response Profile) and MARA-SRV_SERWI (Service Profile) for instance you enter 211 as new selection group. 
  • You click on button Field Selection Maintenance at the end of the line so that the field selection group 211 is displayed.
  • Since these two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tool items, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI. For instance, you can set the radio button for Hide for field reference HALB that is assigned to the material type FHMI. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Example for hiding fields in selection group 211 (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Create a Product for Tools

  • You create a new product for material type FHMI (Production Resource/Tool), for instance SRV_TOOL (Service Tool) for industry sector M (Mechanical engineering).
  • As the configurations are done in customizing, you can maintain data in view Sales: sales org. 2 such as sales organization for instance 1710, distribution channel for instance 10, and item category group SRVT (Service Tool)
  • You can check view Prod.resouces/tools and maintain the work duration for this product.

Figure 5: Product Master view Prod.resources/tools of example product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Controlling Integration

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Integration with Other SAP Components -> Customer Relationship Management -> Settings for Service Processing -> Controlling Integration -> Determine Cost Center and Activity Type for Tool.
  • You assign a cost center and an activity type to the created product SRV_TOOL. (See screenshot in Figure 6.)
  • As for service products, you maintain cost rates for respective cost center and activity type in SAP GUI transaction KP26 or open the following path in SAP Menu: Accounting -> Controlling -> Cost Center Accounting -> Planning ->Activity Output/Prices -> Change.

Figure 6: Example of cost center and activity type assignment to product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Tool Items in Service Transactions

Now let’s process a tool item in service transactions. You can create a service quotation for a service and a tool that is required for execution of the service. (See screenshot in Figure 7.) 

Figure 7: Example of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The duration for the tool item is derived from product master data, in this example two hours. (See screenshot in Figure 8.) 

Figure 8: Example of a duration of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

After accepting, a service order is created as follow-up. Of course, you can create a service order for a service and a tool directly. (See screenshot in Figure 9.) 

Figure 9: Example of a service order tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You enter the actual duration that is used for the tool. In this example three hours, see screenshot in Figure 10.

Figure 10: Example of a service confirmation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You complete the service confirmation. For the service confirmation tool item, a controlling document is created to post actual cost. (See screenshot in Figure 11.) 

Figure 11: Example of a service confirmation (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The actual duration was passed on as quantity to post the actual cost. You can check the quantity in app Service Actuals when item-based accounting is used. (See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Actuals for a tool item when item-based accounting is used (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the enablement of tools and its process in service transactions.

Please don’t hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

For more details, please visit the full product assistance documentation in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Items in Service Orders | SAP Help Portal 
  • Tool Items in Service Transactions | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: The Integrated Toolchain in a Nutshell
entry.content:
Part three of the five-part series, “RISE with SAP Methodology”

If cloud ERP programs were judged purely by technology choices, most would look successful on paper. Platforms are modern. Architectures are sound. Road maps are ambitious.

Yet for many organizations, the lived experience tells a different story. Ask any experienced SAP solution admin or transformation lead where time and energy are really lost, and the answer is almost always execution. Teams fight more with coordination than configuration. Customers often describe it painfully clearly: “We spend more time aligning than delivering.” Fragmentation creeps in where continuity should exist across collaboration, handoffs, rework, and alignment cycles.

This is exactly the challenge RISE with SAP Methodology is designed to address. With the integrated toolchain at its core, the methodology establishes a connected execution backbone that keeps process, architecture, testing, quality, and adoption moving forward together (as shown in the figure).


Figure: The integrated toolchain within RISE with SAP Methodology


How a single transformation backbone is created

The integrated toolchain helps transform ERP landscapes toward SAP Business Suite by orchestrating change holistically across people, processes, applications, and data.

It consists of a variety of solutions that work together to connect design, execution, governance, and long-term operation across the transformation lifecycle:

  • SAP Signavio solutions provide transparency into how business processes run and support fit-to-standard decisions and continuous improvement
  • SAP LeanIX solutions create clarity across the application and integration landscape, supporting a clean core approach and architectural governance
  • SAP Cloud ALM acts as the central system of record for execution, connecting scope, requirements, milestones, risks, testing, and cutover
  • SAP Build solutions enable controlled extensibility and innovation and keep the digital core standardized and upgrade-safe
  • SAP Integration Suite governs and automates integrations across SAP and third-party solutions
  • SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing solution by Tricentis introduces process-driven, automated testing
  • SAP Advanced Data Migration and Management software by Syniti supports early and structured data cleansing, validation, and transformation
  • SAP Archiving and Document Access application by OpenText helps reduce the data footprint and preserve compliance and access to historical documents
  • WalkMe solutions support adoption by guiding users directly in the solution as processes evolve

Collectively, this integrated toolchain enables continuous upgrades, delivers on clean core strategy expectations, accelerates business change, and maintains execution discipline.

A shared system of record is created, one where decisions are made once, documented once, and reused everywhere they matter across phases, teams, and roles. Processes, architecture, requirements, testing, data, integrations, and adoption progress as one connected flow, instead of parallel workstreams hoping to stay aligned.

 
A customer transformation example: Where continuity happens in practice

Suppose a global company is embarking on its move to SAP Cloud ERP Private through the RISE with SAP journey. The goal is not to replicate the past in a new environment, but to simplify processes, reduce customizations, and create a foundation that can evolve over time.

The transformation starts with understanding, not a configuration. While new SAP customers start directly in the discover and onboarding phase with the digital discovery assessment toolkit using the SAP Cloud ALM solution, installed-base customers start with understanding their current state.

Using SAP Signavio solutions, the company’s team gains factual insight into how business processes actually run across regions, highlighting variations, bottlenecks, and improvement potential. In parallel, SAP LeanIX solutions provide visibility into the existing architecture, application landscape, integrations, and dependencies, while the SAP Readiness Check toolset delivers technical insight into custom code and required simplifications.

With this clarity established, execution gains structure. SAP Cloud ALM becomes the central orchestration layer where scope, requirements, milestones, risks, and responsibilities are documented and connected.

Decisions made in workshops no longer disappear into slide decks—they are traceable, actionable, and visible across teams. Data is addressed early using SAP Advanced Data Migration and Management, and SAP Archiving and Document Access helps define which historical data and documents need to remain accessible without burdening the future system.

As the program moves into fit-to-standard discussions, evidence replaces opinion. SAP Signavio solutions provide a clear reference for standard SAP processes, and SAP LeanIX solutions continuously assess the architectural impact of proposed deviations. Where extensions are justified, SAP Build enables application development in a manner that’s clean and upgrade-safe. Integrations are also defined and governed through SAP Integration Suite to help ensure transparency and resilience across the broader ecosystem.

During realization, quality becomes a continuous signal rather than a final checkpoint. SAP Cloud ALM maintains structure across delivery activities. SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis automates testing based on real business processes. Test results, defects, and fixes remain traceable back to original requirements, giving stakeholders a clear view of readiness and risk at all times.

As go-live approaches, cutover planning is no longer a fragile spreadsheet exercise based on assumptive narratives. SAP Cloud ALM brings together testing status, data readiness, integration stability, and archiving decisions into a single, evidence-based view. Leadership decisions about timing and risk are grounded in facts.

After go-live, the same execution backbone continues to support monitoring, stabilization, and continuous improvement. WalkMe solutions guide users directly in the system as processes evolve, while SAP Signavio and SAP LeanIX solutions keep process and architecture transparency intact as new changes are introduced.

As this story proves, the absence of fragmentation is what makes a difference when transitioning and upgrading the IT landscape. No decisions vanish into inboxes. No testing evidence lives on private drives. No critical knowledge depends on heroics. The transformation unfolds as one connected flow—from first insight through ongoing operations.


Why this approach works

In a cloud ERP world defined by continuous change, fragmentation is a structural risk. The integrated toolchain within RISE with SAP Methodology replaces that risk with continuity, transparency, and control.
ERP systems are inherently complex, but hidden complexity doesn’t have to accumulate unnoticed. With a connected system of execution, organizations gain one source of truth. Decisions retain their context and ownership. Testing reflects real-world business use. Clean core strategies make upgrades easier. Continuous improvement becomes possible without rework or documentation resets.

The result is not simply a successful go-live, but a transformation foundation that endures as the business evolves over the long term.

entry.title: Billing Plan Template in Service Order Process
entry.content:
You can use an ad hoc billing plan on service order item to define the dates on which billing is to occur and the value that is to be billed. With this you can bill on specific dates and not just when the service order item is completed. For each billing date, you can enter a billing request line (BRL) manually. 

In this blog I am going to explain how you can use a billing plan template so that the system creates such billing request lines and manual creation is no longer necessary.

First, configurations in Customizing must be completed as prerequisites for the automatic creation of billing request lines in an ad hoc billing plan for a service order item. 

 

Create Billing Plan Template

You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Create Billing Plan Templates.

After you click on Create button, a new entry screen is displayed. You enter a template ID, a description and a long description. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 1.) 

Figure 1: Define details of a new billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on node Billing Plan Template Lines on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You maintain line numbers, descriptions, billing value percentage and a date rule. You can also maintain a billing block reason. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 2.) 

 Figure 2: Define billing plan template lines (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on node Sales Areas of Billing Plan Template on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You maintain a sales organization, a distribution channel and a division for that the billing plan template shall be determined. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 

 Figure 3: Maintain sales are of a billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

You click on node Item Categories of Billing Plan Template on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You choose an item category for that your billing plan template shall be determined. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Choose item categories (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

Activate Billing Plan Template Determination

You check which billing plan type is assigned to your service order item categories in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Assign Billing Plan Type to Item Category. (See screenshot in Figure 5.)

Figure 5: Billing plan type assignment (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Define Billing Plan Types

You select the billing plan type that you have assigned to service order item categories and open the details.

You flag the checkbox of Determine Billing Plan Template. (See screenshot in Figure 6.) and save it.

Figure 6: Activate determination of billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

Use of Billing Plan Template in a Service Quotation

You create a service quotation for customer 17100001 in sales area 1710 as sales organization, 10 as distribution channel, 00 as division. You add an item for service product SRV_01 and quantity 1, and choose the item category SrvItm (Enabl Ad Hoc) (SBQS). (See screenshot in Figure 7.)

Figure 7: Service Quotation Item List (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the details of item 10 and add the assignment block Billing to the overview page. You maintain the previously created billing plan template in the corresponding field. (See screenshot in Figure 8.)

Figure 8: Assignment block Billing (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Or you open the value help, search with the sales area and select the line for determined billing plan template. (See screenshot in Figure 9.)

Figure 9: Value Help for Billing Plan Template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on Apply and save the service quotation. You send this quotation to the customer (service quotation is released). You click on button Accept. With this, a service order is created as follow-up and the service quotation is completed. You use the link on service order in the assignment block Transaction History. The service order is opened and you check that an item is created.

You open the details of this service order item and click on Billing Plan.

You check that two billing request lines are created accordingly to the settings of the billing plan template that you have maintained already in the service quotation item:

  • Billing dates are calculated accordingly to the maintained date rules of the billing plan template lines.
  • Billing values are calculated accordingly to the maintained percentages of the billing plan template lines.
  • Descriptions are copied as maintained on the billing plan template lines.
  • Billing blocks are copied as maintained on the billing plan template lines, in this example no billing block.

(See screenshot in Figure 10.)

Figure 10: Automatically created billing request lines (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

What did the system?

  • The billing plan template is copied directly from the service quotation item to the service order item
  • The copied billing plan template is immediately applied to the service order item.

As a result:

  • Billing request lines for an ad hoc billing plan are created automatically.
  • The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value succeeds and no error message is displayed. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.)

The key benefit is that no additional manual changes are needed on the service order item to achieve a valid ad hoc billing plan.

 

Use of Billing Plan Template in a Service Order

You create a service order without predecessor service quotation. So, you enter customer 17100001 for sales area 1710 as sales organization, 10 as distribution channel, 00 as division.

You add an item for service product SRV_01 and quantity 1, and choose the item category Service (Ad Hoc Bil) (SBOS).

You check that the check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value doesn't result in an error message. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.) 

(See screenshot in Figure 11.)

Figure 11: Service Order Item List  (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the details of service order item 10 and click on Billing Plan.

You check that two billing request lines are created accordingly to the data of the determined billing plan template.

  • Billing dates are calculated accordingly to the maintained date rules.
  • Billing values are calculated accordingly to the maintained percentages.
  • Descriptions are copied
  • As no billing block was used in the billing plan template, no billing block is copied.

(See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Order Item Billing Plan (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

What did the system?

  • The determined billing plan template is immediately applied to the service order item.

As a result:

  • Billing request lines for an ad hoc billing plan are created automatically.
  • The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value succeeds, and no error message is displayed. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.)

The key benefit is that no additional manual changes are needed on the service order item to achieve a valid ad hoc billing plan.

 

Notes

If you create a service order item and the system would determine more than one billing plan template, no billing plan template would be applied. The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value would fail and an error message would be displayed (CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604).

 

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the usage of billing plan templates in service order process.

Please don’t hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q4-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
Happy New Year and cheers to a sustainable year ahead! As we kick off 2026, I’m back with my quarterly blog series about the latest innovations and highlights in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Multi-Impact Categories
  • Streamlined Energy Management
  • Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections
  • Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide
  • BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Additional Information

 

Multi-Impact Categories

One of the most significant innovations this quarter is the introduction of multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, moving the product beyond carbon. Built on the same ERP-driven data foundation, governance model, and auditability, the latest updates extend the calculation engine to cover additional environmental impact categories. This lets you monitor a broader spectrum of environmental pressures without changing the way you integrate data or run calculations.

Think of multi-impact categories as different lenses on how your operations affect the Earth system. Aligned with planetary boundaries, they translate the data you already have into indicators for climate and other dimensions like land use, biosphere integrity, and biogeochemical flows. That means you can see where improvements in one area risk shifting burdens elsewhere – and manage those trade-offs with real numbers.

This matters for reporting because one consistent dataset can now serve multiple frameworks (e.g., CSRD, SBTi FLAG), reducing parallel tools and strengthening credibility with synchronized, audit-ready figures for sustainability, finance, and controlling. But this also matters for decision-making because placing multi‑impact indicators alongside financial and operational KPIs brings sustainability into core business steering. A richer picture of environmental pressure helps identify where reductions also improve efficiency, resilience, and brand value – and where hidden risks accumulate. This supports a shift from compliance‑driven reporting to performance‑driven management, where sustainability becomes a source of competitiveness and innovation.

Importantly, nothing changes in how you run the system. You still reuse ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre‑delivered factors, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that the same setup now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so your existing data and methods serve a growing list of corporate and product requirements – without extra integrations or parallel logic.

Footprint Results with additional Impact Categories

To learn more about this innovation, its business rationale, and how it supports your reporting requirements, check out my deep dive blog post: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. It also includes a step-by-step walkthrough of the overall workflow and the enhanced apps. For complete documentation and technical details, visit SAP Help: Calculating Footprints for Different Impact Categories.

We will also publish additional blog posts in the SAP Community, explaining in detail how you can map the multi-impact calculation results to various reporting requirements. Stay tuned!

 

Streamlined Energy Management

Managing energy data for footprint calculations has often been repetitive and time-consuming. Previously, you had to enter the same energy data and meter readings multiple times for different calculation variants, making workflows cumbersome and prone to errors. This complexity increased further when handling periodic meter readings and energy bills across multiple locations.

With the latest release, we’ve simplified this process significantly: For all newly created footprint calculations, energy bills and meter readings are now managed separately from the footprint inventory using two new types of GHG data forms. This means you can collect periodic energy data via the Record GHG Data app and reuse it across multiple calculations without redundant entries. Data maintenance is now independent of calculation variants, saving time and improving consistency.

We’ve also introduced more flexibility: you can calculate energy-related footprints based on energy sources only, without the need for an energy flow model, which is a major advantage for Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations. The user experience has been improved in the Calculate Footprints app as well, with data readings displayed directly on the first page of the inventory for quick access.

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and what has changed in the existing apps. For the full documentation, see Maintain Energy Bills and Meter Readings Using GHG Data Forms on SAP Help.

To use the new approach, start by preparing your footprint inventory scope. In the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app, activate form-based data collection for energy bills and meter readings. If you plan to use meter readings in your energy flow model, make sure to include Direct Emissions and Energy Consumptions under Value Chain Steps. For energy bills, this step isn’t required.

Define Footprint Inventory Scope with Form-Based Data Collection

Next, configure your energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. When creating an energy source, choose Enter Energy Bills if you want to manage consumption through the Energy Bills form, or Use Meter Readings and Planned Consumptions for meter-based data. Meters themselves are created in the Manage Locations app and must be assigned to the relevant plants. If you include meters in your energy flow model, they need to be in place before creating the footprint inventory.

With the scope and energy sources ready, create GHG data collections for the relevant plants and periods in the Manage GHG Data Collections app. Then, record your periodic energy data in the Record GHG Data app. You can enter values directly in the UI. Alternatively, you can download the template for offline editing and mass upload, or you can use the enhanced API for automating data entry and connecting smart meters – see the following chapter for details. Validation checks help ensure consistency, for example by flagging deviations greater than 30% from previous readings.

Record Meter Readings in GHG Data Form

Finally, run your calculation in the Calculate Footprints app. Newly created inventories no longer show separate tabs for energy bills and meter readings – instead, these values are maintained in the GHG data forms, and the Data Readiness section provides an overview of form status and associated models.

Calculate Footprints: Data Readiness

 

Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections

Managing GHG data across multiple locations and form types can be a challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. That’s why we’re introducing a powerful new capability, allowing mass upload for GHG data forms. You can now upload different types of forms – such as energy bills, meter readings, business activities, and waste data – across locations using a single template in the Record GHG Data and Manage GHG Data Collections apps. The template includes tabs for each form type, making it easy to consolidate and manage data efficiently without repetitive manual entry. For all details, check SAP Help: Working with GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

To take automation even further, the GHG Data Forms API has been enhanced with new endpoints and parameters for mass updates. This means you can retrieve and update forms programmatically, integrate with external systems, and even connect smart meters or IoT devices directly. Check out the API on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: GHG Data Forms.

These improvements reduce manual effort, increase accuracy, and save time. They’re also addressing several of the most requested features on SAP Influence.

 

Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements

High‑quality emission factors are the backbone of accurate and audit‑ready footprint results. The broader and better your factor library, the fewer workarounds you need, the faster you can onboard, and the more confidently you can answer customer and regulatory requests. Last quarter, we’ve expanded the default datasets, improved import templates and governance, and refined AI‑assisted mapping – so you can source, structure, and apply factors with less manual effort and higher precision.

With this release, the Manage Emission Factors app expands its default dataset substantially. We’ve added two new source packages and refreshed an existing one to broaden coverage and improve alignment with logistics and fuel methodologies. Newly added are:

  • GLEC Framework (Smart Freight Centre): Harmonized logistics factors across road, rail, air, ocean/inland waterways, and parcel/last‑mile; coverage for fuels and energy (TTW/WTT), logistics sites and equipment (warehousing, refrigeration, handling), plus rules for distance, allocation, and data quality aligned with ISO 14083.
  • German Environment Agency (Umweltbundesamt, UBA): Factors for fossil fuels including natural gas, hard coal, lignite, heating oils, diesel, gasoline, LPG, and more.

In addition, the UK DEFRA packages have been updated and now include the full set of emission factors. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data on SAP Help.

To make onboarding and governance smoother, and to align with the latest features, we’ve updated the import templates in the Manage Emission Factors app. The simple template (v3) and the LCA template (v5) now support impact categories beyond Climate Change, including the selection of an LCIA method and its characterization factor per dataset – so you can manage multi‑impact content consistently. In the Dataset Sources tab, you can add a source URL to the dataset for traceability, and unit validation has been tightened via the Dimensions column. We also streamlined context fields by adding a drop-down list to the Boundary column and moving it to the Emission Dataset tab to keep dataset‑level semantics in one place. For all changes, visit SAP Help: Emission Factors Data.

With the Custom Datasets feature in the Manage Emission Factor app, you can assemble component datasets into a single, composite dataset to derive an overall emission factor when a product or activity’s direct factor is unknown – leveraging known emissions of its parts to enable accurate footprint calculations. Now, those custom datasets also support multi-impact categories, so you can use it also for emission factors beyond climate change. For more information, see Creating Custom Datasets and Emission Factors on SAP Help.

Custom Dataset with Multi-Impact Emission Factors

We’ve also refined the AI-assisted emission factor mapping in the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app. This powerful feature suggests mappings between products (or product groups) from your ERP system and emission factors from LCA databases. A new option, Show Enhanced Footprint Suggestions, is enabled by default and shifts similarity scores to prioritize commodity code first, then text similarity, then country/region. This enhances mapping precision where commodity codes are available. If your ERP master data or LCA packages lack commodity codes, you can switch the option off to revert to text‑matching. Exact matches are elevated when product names and dataset names align and commodity codes are consistent (or both absent), even if descriptions are missing. To reduce false negatives, AI no longer pre‑filters by unit convertibility and you’ll only be blocked at release if unit conversions are missing in product master data. And for categories with sparse activity‑based data, AI now includes spend‑based factors when they rank among the top 10 suggestions. For all details, check SAP Help: Using AI to Map Emission Factors to Purchased Products and Product Groups.

Refined AI-assisted Emission Factor Mapping with Enhanced Footprint Suggestions

 

Other Release Highlights

To help you better understand your transport network at a glance, we added map visualizations for locations and transport routes across key apps. In the Manage Locations app, you can view locations on an interactive map along with details such as address, geocoordinates, postal code, and country or region. The Manage Transport Activities app now also provides a map-based view of generated routes and legs, helping you visualize transport flows more intuitively. On top of that, the Manage Transport Activities and Calculate Transport Footprints apps include an enhanced quick view for locations with an embedded map display. This means you can access location details and see them on a map instantly, streamlining your workflow and saving time.

Visualization of Transport Route and Legs

In my previous blog post, I introduced the Source Input Items feature in the Manage Footprint Results app that gives granular visibility into the inputs driving product emissions to identify hotspots and guide targeted decarbonization actions. We now enhanced this feature with the ability to generate source input items for cyclical calculations. This makes footprint analysis more comprehensive, especially for products calculated based on cyclical processes. On SAP Help, you find more information about source input items: Viewing the Footprint Results, and examples on cycle calculations: Calculating Cycles.

Another update improves data handling and coverage in the Import Business Transactions app: You can now add business transaction data to supplement imported records, with clear tracking of imported and added entries. New columns – Imported Records, Added Records, and Entry Method – provide transparency on how data enters the system, ensuring complete coverage for footprint calculations. The consolidated data (imported and added records) is then used to calculate footprints. For details, see Import Business Transactions, and for more information about business transactions' behavior, see Business Transactions Types on SAP Help.

Finally, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is now available in two additional regions: Europe (Frankfurt) and Brazil (São Paulo), both on AWS. This expansion supports customers operating in these regions with improved availability and compliance.

 

Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide

To make it easier for you to adopt the latest capabilities, we’ve expanded our enablement portfolio with new content and updates across multiple channels. Together with BearingPoint, we hosted a webinar that gives an overall introduction of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and also takes a closer look at multi-impact categories and what they mean for your sustainability strategy. Supported by a system demo, the session explains how these new dimensions help you move beyond carbon to a more holistic view of environmental performance. If you missed it, you can watch the full recording here:

We’ve also updated the Learning Journey Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations. A new unit now explains how to calculate GHG Scope 3.4 emissions using the ERP-centric transport footprint calculation capabilities introduced last year. This addition is particularly valuable for organizations looking to leverage existing ERP data for transport-related emissions without building parallel processes. It’s a practical guide to help you understand how these capabilities fit into your overall footprint model and reporting requirements.

In addition, we also published a new Scenario Guide that includes detailed process steps for calculating Scope 3.4 emissions based on data already available in your ERP systems: Process 8 – Calculating Scope 3.4 Emissions Using Business Transaction Data.

These enablement updates are designed to make adoption easier and faster, so you can focus on turning sustainability data into actionable insights. Whether you prefer learning through webinars, structured journeys, or detailed guides, we’ve got you covered.

 

BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Recently, I joined the Inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud Podcast to discuss sustainability and share real-world examples of how our solutions create impact. A highlight was my conversation with Maximilian Bauer from BASF Coatings, who explained how they use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to tackle the complexity of sustainability in their business.

BASF Coatings operates in a highly dynamic environment, producing thousands of product variations with every color shade counting as a new product. This creates massive data challenges when calculating footprints. With SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, BASF Coatings can now:

  • Scale and automate carbon footprint calculations for hundreds of thousands of products.
  • Integrate seamlessly into existing systems, embedding sustainability into daily operations.
  • Gain actionable insights to offer more sustainable products and make data-driven decisions.

As Maximilian Bauer said: “You can only improve what you can measure – and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management offers us exactly this.”

Looking ahead, BASF Coatings is moving beyond carbon to multi-impact footprints, covering categories like abiotic resource depletion to ensure responsible use of finite resources. They’re also scaling innovations such as biomass balance and ChemCycling®, replacing fossil-based raw materials with renewable or recycled alternatives. These steps position BASF to meet growing global demand for sustainable products and stay ahead of regulatory expectations.

BASF Coatings’ journey illustrates why we’re evolving SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: from carbon-only to multi-impact sustainability footprints, enabling companies to manage risk, cost, and growth across multiple environmental dimensions – all embedded in core business processes.

In the podcast, I also shared our broader vision: embedding sustainability into business processes, leveraging a single trusted data foundation, and using AI to make sustainability intelligent and scalable. By expanding beyond carbon toward multiple impact categories, we help businesses move from compliance to competitive advantage.

Listen to the full episode on Apple Podcast or Spotify.

 

Additional Information

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

  • Revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com

Revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com

The updated experience delivers a clearer, more intuitive overview of the SAP Activate methodology, highlighting its phased approach, key benefits, real-world customer successes, and easy access to tools, road maps, and learning resources. Whether you’re just starting your cloud journey or deep into an implementation, the refreshed page makes it easier than ever to understand how SAP Activate helps accelerate transformation and drive faster time-to-value. Explore the new page here and see how SAP Activate continues to evolve to support your success.

SAP Activate Community | SAP Activate Blogs | SAP Activate Minute Videos

Join the SAP Activate Community to explore valuable content and resources while connecting with SAP partners, clients and internal colleagues by participating in discussions and sharing knowledge.

Make sure to follow the SAP Activate tag to access blog posts like those highlighted here, along with additional insights shared by SAP Activate experts within the community.

Recap of some blog posts from the community:

  • Introducing the SAP Activate for SAP Business Network for Logistics roadmap by Ana Goetze

  • Deliver quality SAP BTP projects with SAP Activate and partner support services by Jose Bastidas
  • How the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap Answers Your Top 5 Transition Questions by Ana Goetze
  • Who are you? Accountable or Responsible when standing for in the Fit-to-Standard process? by Jair Azevedo

  • Deep Dive: Inside the Framework of RISE with SAP Methodology by Manuel Lederle
  • SAP Activate for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: Scenario-Specific Roadmaps by Kristen Reddington
  • Video: Best Practices to keep up to date on updates and changes in SAP Activate by Jan Musil

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition in 2602

The SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are highlights for this release.

  • Added guidance for system monitoring using SAP Cloud ALM which includes Business Process Monitoring, Integration & Exception Monitoring, User Monitoring, Job & Automation Monitoring, and Health Monitoring. Production Operations Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Expanded the road maps to include a new run phase quality gate and consolidated the adoption plan checklists with the remaining phase gates. All quality gate questions are available as a form in SAP Cloud ALM with enhanced integration to delivery services. Conduct Project Quality Gate for Run Phase
  • Introduced Joule in road map viewer and Joule for Consultants based on Activate content making it more efficient for the customer to find information that they are looking for. 
  • Added a tag to identify the tasks required for the GROW Fast initiative where customers can go live with a fixed scope in 6 weeks.
